node.text:
Educator Shana White discusses how she uses art to bring every student's identity into the classroom. "Identity portraits are a project that allows kids to express their own identities. It's a really big growth point for a lot of kids that they are able to be comfortable with who they are and recognize and respect the identity markers of anybody." 🖌

#Diversity #CulturallyResponsiveTeaching #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #Arts #ArtEducation

node.title: Exploring Perceptions About Identity Through Self-Portraits

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Taking Bold Action for Environmental Change INDIAN COMMUNITY SCHOOL Franklin, Wisconsin @edutopia'.

node.text:
At Indian Community School (ICS) in Franklin, Wisconsin, students are thinking about what they want the world to look like seven generations from now. 

Serving American Indian students in greater Milwaukee, ICS focuses on teaching kids about what it means to be living in an urban American Indian setting, says Jason Dropik, the head of school and a member of the Bad River Band of Lake Superior Chippewa. The school, which has been in operation for 50 years, represents all tribes from Wisconsin, along with other federally and non-federally recognized tribes beyond the state’s borders.

Through the school’s curriculum, students connect directly with tribal communities, such as through field trips to Menominee nation in Keshena, Wisconsin where they study the migration story of American Indian people who lived there. 

Food sovereignty within the indigenous context is also a major focus of the school’s environmental curriculum, says Dropik. Students learn about the history of gaming and fishing as a tool for survival, along with ways to cultivate healthy, sustainable food sources like planting wild rice along the banks of a local river. And for more than a decade, fourth-grade students at the school have been keeping a garden, growing corn, bean, and squash—the “three sisters” or sacred foods in Oneida culture—and have planted maple trees to learn about harvesting sap. 

“[We want] to provide for our families in ways where we don't have to use processed foods, things that have chemicals in them that have been detrimental to our tribal communities,” Dropik explains, referencing obesity rates, diabetes, and other health concerns.

#EnvironmentalEducation #InquiryBasedLearning #PlaceBasedLearning #MiddleSchoolTeacher #HighSchoolTeacher

node.text:
"Think about how it feels to walk into a room where people are excited to see you, and you are welcomed with a smile. There have been events that I have dreaded going to, but when I walked in and was welcomed by name with a huge smile, handshake, or hug, I immediately felt as if I belonged. We all long to have a place in this world to feel we belong. As teachers we have an opportunity each day to be that place for our kids, and it starts the moment they walk through our doors." - Tisha Richmond, Educator and Author

#TeacherQuote #EducationQuote #QOTD #Belonging

We asked teachers what tiny shifts made a difference in their classroom—and their answers surprised us. Just a few words can have a positive impact!

#TeacherTip #TeacherTips #LanguageShifts #TeacherTalk #ClasroomManagement

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, flower and text that says 'LITERACY Using Outlines to Support Student Note-Taking'.

node.text:
Taking notes on reading assignments is a crucial skill that “can help students read for deeper comprehension,” writes Jennifer Davis Bowman, an adjunct professor of education, but unfortunately it “isn’t a skill that comes naturally to many students.”

Davis Bowman explains how teachers can scaffold this skill by providing students with outlines that prompt them to record key points, relevant details, and vocabulary. This process guides students through the reading and builds their confidence, “all of which greases the wheels for learning."

🔑 Select content intentionally: Balance is key. Try not to include too much—or too little. Ask yourself questions like, “How does this heading address the content standards or course expectations?”

📘 Consider readability: The outline should flow with the text, so use terminology students will find in the text. Use visual cues—such as white space and numbered lists—so students have a sense of how much to write and what to prioritize.

☁️ Be consistent: Use a similar number of pages, headings, and prompts for each outline so that the format becomes familiar for students. Make it available at set times—before, during, or after each reading. And use the same writing style in each outline—complete sentences or fragments, for example.

📣 Incorporate active reading strategies: Give students plenty of opportunity to process the material in different ways. Davis Bowman suggests that teachers “ask students to rephrase material in their own words… and create analogies to explore relationships between key concepts.”

🗒️ Plan for challenges: If you’re noticing low performance on formative assessments, Davis Bowman advises asking students about what works well for them in other classes: “Are there other note-taking strategies that they’ve found easier to follow? Does the outline method work for them when they’re preparing for tests?”

📷 Evaluate the effectiveness of your outlines: Notice the types of questions that students ask, and when they ask, and look for trends. Ultimately, Davis Bowman says, “You want to look at the big picture: Does the time you take to prepare reading outlines have a clear positive outcome?”

node.text:
It’s time to rethink our definition of what a “good school” is, researchers assert in a new study.⁣
⁣
That’s because the usual signals we rely on to gauge the quality of a school—namely, high test scores—are often incomplete and misleading, the researchers found. ⁣
⁣
The study looked at over 150,000 ninth-grade students who attended Chicago public schools and concluded that schools that emphasize the social and emotional dimensions of learning—relationship-building, a sense of belonging, and resilience, for example—improve high school graduation and college matriculation rates for both high- and low-income students, beating out schools that improve test scores.⁣
⁣
In an interview with Edutopia, C. Kirabo Jackson, the lead researcher and a professor of education and social policy at Northwestern University, explained that schools with robust impacts on student well-being aren’t getting the recognition they deserve. Students in these schools not only have a more positive experience, but are also more likely to graduate and attend college, especially “vulnerable student populations who don’t tend to do very well in the education system,” Jackson said.⁣
⁣
The findings emphasize the need to take a multi-pronged approach to student well-being, and are a reminder that schools—and teachers—can influence students in ways that are difficult to measure, and may only materialize well into the future.⁣

#EducationResearch #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #SocialEmotionalDevelopment #StudentWellBeing #TeachersOfInstagram

node.text:
Like many math teachers, Crystal Frommert was used to questions like “What can I do to get my average up to an A?” and “How many points off if I forgot units?”⁣
⁣
She wished the middle and high school students she taught over the years were focused on learning, but rather than blame them, she reflected on how she had “contributed to the grade-obsessed culture” by praising students “based on their grades rather than their effort and improvement.”⁣
⁣
So she and a group of teachers at her school shared strategies and resources to de-emphasize grades in their classes—“even though we still had to give them.”⁣
⁣
1. Adjust your language: Rather than using threatening statements about grades, Frommert shifted to encouragement, such as, “You did really well with simplifying radicals. I’m looking forward to seeing how you apply that skill to the Pythagorean theorem.”⁣
⁣
She also shifted her language with parents: “I would email or call with information about the concepts or skills their child was demonstrating rather than emphasizing grades,” she writes.⁣
⁣
2. Delay the grade: Frommert began to grade tests with the usual marks—but did not write any point deductions or a grade on the test itself. Afterward, she asked students to reflect and make corrections that they then discussed with her.⁣
⁣
3. Lower the stakes: Frommert stopped recording completion grades for homework and started emphasizing it as a “chance to practice and explore.” She also dropped each student’s lowest quiz grade each term.⁣
⁣
4. Provide retakes: Frommert’s high school math department had a policy of “offering a retake test per term to replace the lowest test grade,” she writes.⁣
⁣
5. Allow self-grading: Research shows that giving grades can have detrimental effects. One way teachers can counter that is through “giving students more ownership of their assessment” by having them complete their own rubric, which can lead to productive conversations with students and boost their metacognitive skills.⁣
⁣
Link in bio.⁣
